comments.commentBody:
Thank you, Mr. Krugman , for stating the situation so clearly. The struggle between Democracy which looks to the needs of all and plutocracy which favors the protection of vast wealth is indeed at the root of our political conflicts.

Plutocrats have successfully sold their ideas to many who are hurt by those very ideas playing on fears of government and loss of individual rights which has been a strong undercurrent throughout our history. Gail Collins the other day made a strong case for a dichotomy between the viewpoints of the city dweller who sees the need for good government and those in the hinterlands who hang onto feeling s of individuality and resent what they see as unneeded controls. And these divisions have been very convenient for the plutocrats.

Mr. Pickety on his masterpiece on capitalism makes the strong case for fair, effective government as a requirement for any social growth. He sites this as the main difference between advanced societies and ones whose growth is stunted and as Republicans attempt to destroy our government for political reasons we are about to become a 3rd world example of this.

I find the contrast between Mr. Uwayesu and the other inhabitants of the dump to be a remarkable story in that he was able to overcome the fear that is prevalent in such situations. I have recently noticed that different people here in Oakland are more or less fearful in ways that can mean the difference between mediocrity and success. In particular, I noticed people in a poorer area in Oakland who were more afraid of being out late in their neighborhood than I am.

I applaud Mr. Uwayesu, but I would hope that someone would find a way to get more people in his situation to overcome their fear so that they can strive for something better, not just in Rwanda, but anywhere in the world.

Their simple rebuttal to this by neo classical economics is powerful because it is like pablum. "But consumer goods are cheaper. Therefore, the loss of pensions means nothing. The poor can get cheaper shoes at Walmart. So they are wealthy !" Of course if the  shoes fall apart after 6 months it doesn't matter. Especially if the people who bought them die of exposure because they can't afford a roof over their heads.
No, that is not a powerful rebuttal.

Nothing is going to change until there is a political opposition to the right that is unafraid, unashamed, unapologetic to forcefully, resolutely call out the Big Lie of conservative economic ideas and policies. Conservative ideology must have the heart cut out of it.

- "free" markets: the idea that the public should have no say in setting the rules that determine the OS of the economy.
- Invisible Hand: the idea that selfish, short-term private self-interest solves all society's problems
- government bad: the idea that the public operating collectively to do what only the collective can and must do is bad

These ideas have to be destroyed, root and branch.

Neo-classical economists have done enormous damage to the country and world in coming to the aid of the plutocrats giving them the meme that infect the body politic. It's time for them to undo it. It's time for the right's political opposition -- the Democrats -- to cease with their acts of political cowardice and lead the country and world back to sanity as it pertains to economics.

And both of them better get started. People didn't deserve this garbage they've been served up by economists and right wing politicians and they deserved better than the tawdry spinelessness of the Democrats in facing it.

Thanks a ton, Jim Baughman, for giving us the HOE down on 25A!

Howie

For someone claiming to be "self-monitoring" for Ebola,
Dr. Spencer: Went jogging, no doubt building up quite a sweat.
Travelled on several subway lines.
Went bowling.
Drank and dined at a restaurant, where he undoubtedly
handled and used glassware and ate with a knife, fork and spoon.
Most likely used the restroom.
I wonder if the busboy and dishwasher at that restaurant have been warned?
It almost sounds as if he was attempting to spread Ebola.
Incidentally, from the CDC: Mortality rate for influenza,
circa 2011: 0.0005%, mainly elderly and infants.
Mortality rate for Ebola: 50% to 90%, across all age groups.

The guy spent a month in the heart of the epidemic in close contact with severely sick and highly infectious patients and no doubt their bodily fluids. Isn't it amazing that so many do this and do NOT catch it?

The fact that he caught it makes perfect sense and does not scare me. The part that scares me is that he had such poor judgment as to travel on the subway and go to crowded public places completely unnecessarily. He should have self-imposed a full quarantine but at the very least limit travel and avoid public transportation. That he failed so miserably to do that is the part that makes no sense to me and scares me.

It's also anxiety-provoking that Doctors Without Borders (obviously an exceptional organization but still prone to mistakes) has so far been so weaselly about what exact protocol is imposed on returning doctors and whether this guy violated it. And I would really like to hear some reassurance that from now on 21-day quarantines will be required of all returning medical personnel.
And since there are only 4 beds in the isolation unit at Bellevue, may very few additional people in NY contract this disease.

May he get well, may those with whom he had contact not become ill. May we have so called " altruistic" professionals who are also able to " think", to apply coomon sense. It's no different than the sick person standing next to you at an event who just had to come, would not simply stay home. The similar mentality of a coworker who comes to the office with a fever of 101 and makes everyone sick. The problem is that this disease bears potential for greater adverse effects. The Dallas nurse had to go to Cleveland, so did Dr. Spencer need to play with friends without considering the harm that might ensue. She is now Ebola free, he is beginning his journey. May no harm result from his choices.

Is it really too much to expect that a Dr. who has been in Africa and recently in contact with Ebola patients quarantine himself long enough to assure us he doesn't have the disease.  If we can't depend on the individuals to police themselves, then the government needs to lock them up by force.

Denial is powerful; fear even more.

And fear spread much more quickly than Ebola. And certainly can has costs.

We balk at flu vaccinations when 26,000 die from the disease every year, but fail into frenzy of this disease that has killed one so far. Let's revisit in 6 months and see if this has led to even a fraction of the deaths caused by diseases we know and accept.

Yes, you are right, this IS pure speculation. And not very reasonable either. Someone flies all the way to West Africa to put his life on the line trying to save people's lives, and your judgement of his character is that he is too selfish to miss 10 nights of bowling and city life? Very simplistic...He was monitoring his temperature twice daily, as mentioned in the article.
yes, it is pure speculation, better not said at all.

No need to indulge in "pure speculation" and conspiracy theories. He made a terrible, stupid error, that is true. But really, without a clue, you go on speculating about how he might have known he had been exposed, plotted to return to the US and then blithely traveled around NYC? Get a grip.

"Dr. Spencer had been working with Doctors Without Borders in Guinea treating Ebola patients, and completed his work on Oct. 12, Dr. Bassett said. He flew out of the country on Oct. 14, traveling via Europe, and arrived in New York on Oct. 17."

This is pure speculation, but if symptoms typically appear 8-10 days after exposure, it is entirely plausible that Dr. Spencer knew he had been exposed to the Ebola virus and chose to immediately travel back to the US. Do we have confirmation that "he completed his work" with Doctors Without Borders? If he knew he had been exposed (torn personal protective equipment, etc.), then he had all the more ethical responsibility to completely isolate himself and NOT go bowling, take the subway, etc.

Look, people. If he was really not symptomatic he posed no danger on the subways. Eves, it is the worst kind of hyperbole to say that he exposed thousands. People with the flu would pose more danger of passing that infection on in the subway. The flu virus can be airborne.

That said, it might be a good idea to self-quarantine for 21-days upon return from caring for Ebola patients instead of just self-monitoring. It would be interesting to know what MSF advises. However, what he did hardly warrants suspension of a medical license and arrest . If he hopped into a taxi to ride to Bellevue once he had a fever and gastrointestinal symptoms that would be one thing. But he contacted MSF, which contacted the health department and he was transported by prepared EMS personnel. Let it rest. Wish him well...

Absolute condescending hogwash W.A.! A medical professional can be as negligent as any other person in his own life. It's just part of being human. He should be spearheading a mandatory quarantine for all returning health care workers to Africa.

Spitzer: Three medical professionals have come back to the US infected. Two were brought back, true. But these professionals, supposedly in full protective gear, still contracted the disease. How many others have come back without being tested?

I don't need to be one to count.

Time to get realistic

So what?  He put a city of 8 million people at risk by traveling on the subway, using a taxi cab. He brought Ebola to the United States.  He may be a medical professional but either he lacks common sense or he has an overgrown sense of entitlement because he is a humanitarian worker and a physician.  The CDC lost a lot of credibility with the public for its laconic response in Dallas.  The list of errors is a mile long.  I was in Taiwan during SARS, had medical issues which resulted in sudden fevers and was quarantined in "an abundance of caution."  It was boring but I didn't die from it or put others at risk.

I don't get it.  A person who was treating Ebola patients was allowed to return to this country without being taken into/unto medical supervision, was simply left to his own resources?  What am I missing?  Mindboggling.

I think those of us who have never volunteered to help the sick in West Africa would be better off keeping this type of opinion to ourselves. These doctors and nurses forego their salaries and put themselves in harm's way to help others. God bless them.

Arkansas has been bombarded by millions of dollars of misleading and false advertising in the last few election cycles, much of it from out of state. Arkansas is also no longer a state that takes in more than it gets from the feds now, so the argument in favor of lower taxes and smaller government sells. Finally, the Obama administration didn't do Democrats any favors by waiting until the 2014 tornado season to visit the state. Folks forget that Arkansas was hit two nights in a row before the storms rolled into Birmingham, and the feds appeared to be helping Exxon not the people during the devastating Mayflower oil catastrophe.
All in all, I still think 90% of Arkansans would do better to vote Democrat, and Tom Cotton thinks he's better than 99% of the people in his state, but you have to understand that their votes for Republicans aren't completely out of left field.

Since this isn't true, "the author" could hardly be aware of it.  Dan Kahan's point was much subtler than that but certainly did not mention 50:50 on the obvious and well established physics of the consequences of accumulating heat-trapping greenhouse gases and increasingly the energy in our system, or of other forms of planetary exploitation and dumping.
Our prayers go out to this doctor and his family. Hopefully, he'll get better medical care than Mr. Duncan did, and he will defeat this hideous disease.

No one forced the doctor to treat ebola-stricken patients. If you are going to take on that responsibility, then you should be careful not to be reckless by putting the larger public at risk. What does it matter if he saved 20 lives in one country, but eventually put a city of 8 million at risk? That's just reckless and he should lose his medical license. I certainly would not want someone that reckless and irresponsible rendering medical advice to me. And why should he have to wait until he feels symptoms?? They should self-quarantine BEFORE any symptoms for safety purposes. If you're scared of violence, then don't be a police officer If you don't know how to exhibit caution for public safety, then don't be doctor. Simple as that.

He was exposed to Ebola in Africa.  He should have had the good sense to stay in quarantine for at least two weeks after leaving.  He's a doctor for heaven's sake.  You can't say he didn't know what he was doing.  He deserves to be severely reprimanded for his carelessness.

In more than 230 years of Constitutional democracy, we have failed to secure it. Because it has been allowed to calcify and become corrupted, it can be attacked. We could lose it. It could be snatched away like a poor man's last meal.

We have a system that encourages passive citizens. The role of the "masses" is to stand around a cheer when speeches are made, then shut up and vote.

The men who fashioned our democracy were of the landed gentry. Many had deep doubts about the concept of democracy and others wanted no part of it. The result was that the founders created a hobbled democracy where only one national body, the House, was to be elected directly by the people. Even now, the tea party crowd in Texas advocates returning the selection of US Senators to state legislatures, something that would further remove the Senate from the will of the people.

We can not have democracy if we aren't willing to defend it. Hundreds of thousands of men have died to give us and then preserve this great gift. It is being chipped away by these new "poll taxes", photo ID requirements. It will be subject to successive attacks.

We must protect and expand democracy and then ensure DISTRIBUTION, not re-distribution, of the wealth that the whole nation creates. Someone who is paid insufficiently to support themselves and their children is living in a kind of modern slavery. Democracy will not ensure good outcomes, but it might be the only chance to achieve them.

http://terryreport.com

Stop, just stop RIGHT NOW placing any blame for this disease on this doctor.

We should be saying THANK YOU a million times over to the people who are willing to put their own lives on the line, such as the physicians with MSF. Unless you're willing to do exactly the same, hush up now. The man is SICK with the same dreadful disease he was helping to cure. How incredibly unseemly, to shake your finger at him for having the nerve to go bowling. Let's hope he gets well so we can give him a hero's celebration.

steve I, IMHO, You deftly managed to hit the nail squarely on the CONK...Just sayin'.

WHH

Agreed with everything except your statement about "Big Pharma."  The fact is, half of the proteins that make up Ebola's functions are still unknown.  Its not easy to study these proteins when the virus is engaging in micro-breaks in rural and isolated Central Africa.  Your statement about profits would imply that Pharmaceutical companies never produce a drug if it would generate losses, something that is not actually supported by real world data.  In addition, it implies an entire lack of any social responsibility atmosphere in a company or corporation, again, something that is not supported by real world information.  Finally, Pharmaceutical companies had been studying and testing treatments for Ebola since the first outbreak in the 1970s.  That's the only reason any treatment was available to those suffering from the current outbreak, and the only reason such a treatment was even made available was because WHO and several national organizations have momentarily changed their ethics policies to allow treatments that have not been subjected to the entirety of their safety and health standards to be administered to those suffering from Ebola now, as a form of impromptu human clinical trials.  Without such approval, the treatment would have been reduced to the standard RCTs and R&D techniques, meaning it may never have been allowed to reach the market to begin-with, generating huge losses for the company in the process.

There are no flights from these countries! Have you ever traveled to Africa?Travelers from Guinea to New York arrive on connections from Paris or Zurich. All these demands to "stop the flights" are pure demagoguery. There are no flights.

Unless we want to seal our borders from European travel, it's a much more complex logistical problem that would require putting people arriving from Paris back on planes if we determine they were in, say, Guinea in the recent past. It's not stopping the non-existent flights.

It's not hard for the government to look at the passports of ANYONE reentering from an international flight, see that someone was in a country with a high rate of the Ebola virus, and put the person in quarantine for 21 days.

@Martin
No one is talking about stopping airplanes -- a travel ban would simply stop incoming *travelers* who have been in west Africa within the last 21 days. And it's incredibly easy to do just by checking passports.

The fact that there are no direct flights is irrelevant and we wouldn't need to stop planes coming from Europe or anywhere else. It doesn't matter where a traveler has been or how many planes were changed during transit. All international passports are stamped upon entry to a new country, providing a date-stamped record of every passenger's travel history.

Air travel from known Ebola-endemic countries should be stopped. Healthcare and other emergency workers and personnel can be flown in and out on military planes with much more control and very little comparative risk.
Everyone, no exceptions, traveling via any mode of transportation from any part of the world where Ebola is endemic should be quarantined for 21 days and subject to very stiff penalties, including prison time and/or deportation, for violating the quarantine. Yes, enforcement would be required, but if we can afford trillions to protect the American public from terrorism, we can afford the comparative pittance to protect it from the Ebola virus which, incidentally, could wipe out half of the U.S. population given current survival rates.

I posted elsewhere in this thread about how interests in the state have changed.  If people have fallen for the campaign ad lies--and we have been deluged with out-of-state-promoted lies--and considering that federal support for AR has fallen, it may not be so crazy for people to considering voting, say, Libertarian.  I wouldn't, but please don't assume it's all ignorance.

I wonder if there would have been less hysteria if when Dr Frieden first publicly addressed the prospects for ebola in the US, he had emphasized that cases of Ebola here were inevitable, rather than assuring us that they would be rare.

I do not remember his having told us that four centers had been set up specifically to treat people who had extremely dangerous illnesses like ebola and having named them.

The CDC's having revised several times the protocol for those caring for ebola patients surely raised people's apprehension rather than reassuring them that the CDC were on top of things. For many took those revisions not as a sign that the CDC were profiting from experience but that the CDC were incompetent.

"my take on this is that perhaps the mortality rate information should be expanded to say that the death rate is over 50% in countries where there is inadequate medical care, and poor sanitary conditions"

Claudia, you are in your own way spreading misinformation. There is no cure or meaningful treatment for Ebola. Basically in a USA hospital they can give you IV hydration and maybe you'll get some plasma infusions. It is all wait and see as far as "treatment" goes. So, the 50% fatality rate is real and you shouldnt make up your own rules about that.

Recently The CDC thinks the fatality rate might be even higher, as more statistics are gathered.

". . . we're not all going to die from this disease"

True.

But 70% of those who contract it and don't get the sort of care available, so far, to at most a few dozen patients, will die. They will contract the disease, not from sewage, not from poor sanitation. From person to person contact, such as that visited upon innocent New Yorkers, in subways, restaurants, and more, by the self-sacrificing Dr. Spencer.

So, how many deaths should we accept before we take it seriously? A number, please. Ten? A thousand? How many?

And, by that time, without the high level of quarantine and care needed to fight this scourge available to more than a small percentage of those infected, panic will ensue, and it will spread . . . everywhere.

The realistic approach to avoiding that scenario is to take maximum precautions now, right away, before it occurs, not wait until the need is obvious and the plague unstoppable.

Everyone take a deep breath and once you've pulled yourself together and started thinking clearly consider this: until this most recent case of Ebola in this country, there have been six people in the US with the disease. The two health care workers who contracted the virus in Liberia, the cameraman from NBC, the two nurses in Dallas and the Liberian man who came here from Liberia. What we're hearing regarding the mortality rate of this disease is that it kills over 50% of the people who contract it. Yet, the only person who has died in this country is the unfortunate patient who was sent home from an unprepared and incompetent emergency room with a fever over 103-degrees, despite the fact that he said he was from Liberia. So, although I'm not a statistician, my take on this is that perhaps the mortality rate information should be expanded to say that the death rate is over 50% in countries where there is inadequate medical care, and poor sanitary conditions: third world countries in essence. Nigeria, a highly-developed nation with a robust economic and medical infrastructure, has essentially eliminated Ebola. The hysteria people are exhibiting at this point in time is truly frightening in its scope. Pull yourselves together folks, we're not all going to die from this disease. But there always has to be something doesn't there to keep people scared to death?
